doc.title: DIALIGN

description.text: DNA and protein sequence alignment based on segment-to-segment comparison

doc.reference: B. Morgenstern (1999). DIALIGN 2: improvement of the segment-to-segment approach to multiple sequence alignment. Bioinformatics 15, 211 - 218.

interface.label: Nucleic acid or protein alignment (-n) Protein (p) Nucleic (n)

xhtml:div.label: Threshold (-thr)

Clustering type used to construct sequence tree?
UPGMA Maximum linkage (-max_link) Minimum linkage (-min_link)
"maximum or minimum linkage" clustering used to construct sequence tree (instead of UPGMA).

Iterative scoring scheme (-it)?
Yes No
iterative scoring scheme (fragment scores are based on conditional probabilities given the previously aligned fragments. I.e. the probability of a fragment -- and therefore its score -- is not based on the probability of random occurrence in the input sequences but rather on the probability of occurrence between those fragments that have already been accepted in previous iteration steps).

Overlap weights (-iw)?
Yes No
overlap weights switched off (by default, overlap weights are used if up to 35 sequences are aligned). This option speeds up the alignment but may lead to reduced alignment quality.

Translation of nucleotide diagonals into peptide diagonals (-nt)?
Yes No
Input sequences are nucleic acid sequences and `nucleic acid segments' are translated to `peptide segments'.

Strand to looked at Watson and Crick strands (-cs)?
Yes No
If segments are translated, not only the `Watson strand' but also the `Crick strand' is looked at

Mixed alignments (-ma)?
Yes No
`mixed alignments' consisting of P-fragments and N-fragments if nucleic acid sequences are aligned.

Dna alignment speed up (-ds)?
Yes No
Non-translated nucleic acid fragments are taken into account only if they start with at least two matches. Speeds up DNA alignment at the expense of sensitivity.

Long genomic sequences (-lgs)?
Yes No
combines the following options: -ma, -it, -thr 2, -lmax 30, -smin 8, -nta, -ff, -fop, -ff, -cs, -ds, -pst

Long genomic sequences (-lfs_t)?
Yes No
Like "-lgs" but with all segment pairs assessed at the peptide level (rather than 'mixed alignments' as with the"-lgs" option). Therefore faster than -lgs but not very sensitive for non-coding regions.

Maximum number of * characters representing degree similarity (-stars)?
The number of `*' characters below the alignment reflects the degree of local similarity among sequences. More precisely: They represent the sum of `weights' of diagonals connecting residues at the respective position.
By default, no stars are used but numbers between 0 and 9, instead.

Mask not aligned residues (-mask)?
Yes No
residues not belonging to selected fragments are replaced by `*' characters in output alignment (rather than being printed in lower-case characters)

Alignment in fasta format (-fa)?
Yes No
Be aware that only upper-case letters are regarded to be aligned in fasta output file.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: "maximum or minimum linkage" clustering used to construct sequence tree (instead of UPGMA).

iterative scoring scheme (fragment scores are based on conditional probabilities given the previously aligned fragments. I.e. the probability of a fragment -- and therefore its score -- is not based on the probability of random occurrence in the input sequences but rather on the probability of occurrence between those fragments that have already been accepted in previous iteration steps).

Input sequences are nucleic acid sequences and `nucleic acid segments' are translated to `peptide segments'.
If segments are translated, not only the `Watson strand' but also the `Crick strand' is looked at
`mixed alignments' consisting of P-fragments and N-fragments if nucleic acid sequences are aligned.
Non-translated nucleic acid fragments are taken into account only if they start with at least two matches. Speeds up DNA alignment at the expense of sensitivity.
combines the following options: -ma, -it, -thr 2, -lmax 30, -smin 8, -nta, -ff, -fop, -ff, -cs, -ds, -pst

Like "-lgs" but with all segment pairs assessed at the peptide level (rather than 'mixed alignments' as with the"-lgs" option). Therefore faster than -lgs but not very sensitive for non-coding regions.

The number of `*' characters below the alignment reflects the degree of local similarity among sequences. More precisely: They represent the sum of `weights' of diagonals connecting residues at the respective position.
By default, no stars are used but numbers between 0 and 9, instead.
residues not belonging to selected fragments are replaced by `*' characters in output alignment (rather than being printed in lower-case characters)
Be aware that only upper-case letters are regarded to be aligned in fasta output file.
